paragraphs: Margaret Kerwin is the first of her siblings to leave Ireland. By 24, she's been in the United States for four years and just married to Irish-born John Lawlor.

images.alt: A scanned photograph of a brick factory along a set of railroad tracks
images.caption: Homer F. Basset, Waterbury and her Industries, 1889.

paragraphs: A gritty industrial city of approximately 100,000, situated at the Naugatuck and Mad Rivers in central Connecticut, Waterbury had been the center of the American brass industry since the early 19th century.

images.alt: A handdrawn map of the city in 1899.
images.caption: Landis and Hughes Map of Waterbury, 1899. Library of Congress.

paragraphs: Margaret's younger sister, Katie, moves in with her family. A single 23-year-old, Katie starts a job at American Mills.
It's not uncommon for immigrants to follow their families into the United States, putting down roots in small neighborhoods resembling their close-knit communities back home.

images.alt: A modest 3-story home with a pink exterior and metal fence.

paragraphs: Margaret's home, built in 1885, is one of those packed immigrant households. Her modest 3-story home contains 500-square-foot floors in which she crams 5 children, her husband, and her sister.

images.alt: A small church with a single steeple.
images.caption: Homer F. Basset, Waterbury and her Industries, 1889.

paragraphs: The Kerwins are members of the Church of Immaculate Conception. The church, dedicated in 1857, was the first in Waterbury built specifically to be a Catholic church.

In the same year that Margaret's family moves away to Philadelphia, her younger brother James follows in from Ireland. He takes over the rented house with Katie.
Katie moves out of the shared apartment when James marries Hannah Murphy.
As James and Hannah start their family, James's brother Martin moves into the city with his wife, Elizabeth Bergin, and their son, John Joseph.
Martin had been living in Naugatuck, a neighboring town, since his arrival in 1900. He married Elizabeth in 1903, and they had John in 1905.
Katie moves again, this time with her new husband, Thomas J. Byrne.

As brothers Martin and James continue to grow their families, their brother Michael finally catches up to them in Waterbury. Michael and his wife, Bridget Agnes Murphy, have a newborn named John Francis.
Newlyweds Katie and Thomas move to Detroit, Michigan.

heading: Brass Mills

images.alt: Large wooden waterwheels among remains of stone buildings surrounded by large trees.
images.caption: Original waterwheels, Waterbury Brass Company, ca. 1910. University of Connecticut Libraries.

paragraphs: Many Irish immigrants found work in the manufacturing industry, which, by the early 20th century, was quickly gaining momentum. In particular, the brass industry in Waterbury began in the mid-18th century and provided an alternative for people struggling to make a living off the rocky, exhausted soil.

images.alt: An old photo of a brass factory on a grass hill.
images.caption: Homer F. Basset, Waterbury and her Industries, 1889.

paragraphs: When Michael got his first job in Watebury at the Waterbury Brass Company, it sat humbly on a grass hill.

heading: Humble Beginnings
paragraphs: Waterbury's first generation of brass manufacturers did not set out to create a brass industry. Their initial goal was to produce buttons and clocks to be sold by peddlers as an alternative to farming, which was a limited success in Waterbury.

images.alt: A vintage catalogue of products by Waterbury Clock Company.

paragraphs: Factories were churning out all kinds of metal products, including silverware, metal hoses, buttons, clocks, and watches.

heading: Godparents
paragraphs: Sometime between 1913 and 1916, James and Hannah die unexpectedly. The cause of death is unclear.
Their children get separated. Jeremiah goes on to live with Hannah's sister in Connecticut, and Anne gets unofficially adopted by Katie and Thomas in Detroit.

heading: World War I
paragraphs: While Waterbury's brass industry had been established in the 19th century and steadily growing ever since, World War I was the catalyst for the city's industrial ramp-up.

Scovill Manufacturing Company, like many others in Waterbury at the time, was a button manufacturer, but, during the war, became a top manufacturer of brass shells and time fuses to supply to American forces.

images.caption: Archives & Special Collections at the Thomas J. Dodd Research Center, University of Connecticut Libraries.
images.alt: Large crowd of workers listening to man standing on platform. Stone buildings in background, one with awnings. Other buildings and gated plant entrance shown.

paragraphs: During the war, laborers often attended patriotic rallies, like this one at the Coe Manufacturing Company in Torrington. Coe Manufacturing was owned by American Brass, one of the leading brass manufacturers of the 20th century.

heading: Scovill

images.alt: An aerial view of a factory with smokestacks and residential area surrounding.

paragraphs: Scovill Manufacturing was another leading company, whose large slew of factories sat along the Mad River in central Waterbury.

Today, all that remain of the company are the abandoned office buildings. The mills have been replaced by retail buildings, restaurants, and a large parking lot that covers a portion of the Mad River.

By the mid-1920s, over 20 years have passed since the first generation of Kerwin brothers—Martin, Michael, and the late James—arrived in Waterbury. By now, their sons are becoming old enough to join them in the brass mills.
Martin's eldest son, John Joseph, is the first of his generation to begin work. At 19, he starts his first job at the American Brass Company.
